 I am a white female, both conservative and liberal (depends on the issue at hand), and have been on this earth quite awhile. I supported integration and affirmative action. I teach and have taught for many years at a public high school located near a military base, so our school is very diverse. We have students from or who have lived in 83 different countries, many with parents from those various countries. Overall, our students get along with one another very well (as always, there are exceptions, but generally speaking we have very few racial/ethnic/religious conflicts). For over 38% of our students, English is not their first language or the primary language spoken in the home. As a Sociology and World History teacher the diversity is a teaching dream. Having said all of the above, this is why I no longer support affirmative action.
 
 Affirmative action is a new type of discrimination in that it is not equally applied to all minorities. In the last 5 years, I have seen tensions rise to unbelievable levels over the issue of minority scholarships. I have seen friendships break-up over black students getting preferential treatment over hispanic students. I have witnessed fights over black females (counts as 2 quota points - 1 for black, 1 for female) getting preferential treatment over black males. Asian and white students want me to explain why it's fair that they have to compete with everyone for general scholarships, but others have scholarships for their specific groups, AND get to compete for the general scholarships. All the work of integration and its positive benefits is being lost when people believe that there is one set of rules for a group and a different set of rules for another group. In this I think we are being short-sighted. Doing one thing to help the people in society learn about one another (integration) and undoing the good by making people think they are being treated unfairly (inequity in scholarship distribution) seems to defeat the original purpose.

AA has been around for 30 plus years, mainly designed to "compensate" for the injustices done to blacks pre-civil rights. I have many students who fall into this category, truly believing that the "government" should pay their way in life because the family has been living on welfare, excuse me "social programs" for generations. I use this example in class when the students talk about the government paying for everything. Question: "Where do you think the government gets its money from?" Answer: "Taxpayers." Question: "Who are the taxpayers?" Answer: "People who work."
